SafetyInspectionBy: Glenn County Air Pollution Control District (CUPA)

_accidents.CF_Other: Blockage in the Aqua Ammonia blimp
_accidents.CI_OtherType: retrained staff not to utilize the equipment if not working properly.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Information

The facility provides both wholesale and retail products to the agricultural end user.   This operation continues to supply aqueous ammonia to the end user for agricultural fertilization.  Aqueous ammonia is loaded at the facility and delivered to the field for application.  All personal information, addresses, and telephone numbers were rechecked for applicability.

Five Year Accident History

There have been no reportable spills or releases in the last five years, and no injuries or illnesses that were caused by ammonia products.

Emergency Response and Accident Prevention Program

The facility continues to be committed to following all applicable safety and reporting regulations for the storage and transport of ammonia products.  There is an emergency plan in place covering response to releases, and it is presented in annual emergency response training for all involved personnel.  

Worst and Alternate Case Scenarios

Both scenarios were evaluated and remodeled using RMP comp.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Wilbur-Ellis is committed to continuously making safety improvements. To improve the safety of the

ammonia system and all other aspects of operations, Wilbur-Ellis is in the process of implementing a comprehensive safety process to help guide facility employees to safe operations on all aspects of the job.  The safety process is designed to be implemented in steps, step one being the fundamentals and foundational elements of an en-grained safety culture and program. 

The process takes a risked based approach to safety and provides guides for each safety program that provides the elements required to implement that program effectively and the methods on how to execute those elements.  Wilbur-Ellis is committed to putting safety first and creating a culture where behavior based safety can thrive.   Our safety program includes measures for tracking progress and success, and addressing opportunities for improvement within the proce

ss and our individual programs.  

Wilbur-Ellis is also implementing a facility-wide comprehensive corrective action/preventative action tracker to facilitate completion of listed CAs on a timely basis. Recommended

improvements and identified deficiencies from the inspection checklists, compliance audits, and PHA studies will be included on the facility Action Tracker along with the priority, employee responsible, and targeted completion dates.



To improve the safety of ammonia and all other aspects of operations, Wilbur-Ellis has implemented a comprehensive, risk-based safety management process to help guide employees to improved safety performance. The safety management process, branded Guiding People to Safety (GPS), is designed to be implemented in four steps, step one comprising of the foundation and fundamental elements of a strong safety program and positive safety culture. The GPS process provides guidelines for each safety program that describe methods for effective implementation. The GPS program includes measures for tracking progress and success and for addressing opportunities for improvement within the process and individual safety programs. These measures include action tracking software to facilitate timely corrections of deficiencies and recommended improvements identified during inspections, audits, and hazard analyses. Wilbur-Ellis is committed to preventing incidents cultivating a positive safety culture throughout the company. The mission of our Environmental Health, Safety and Security (EHSS) team is to drive effective results in reducing incidents and employee injuries by combining the GPS process with a positive safety culture.
